Before we continue, however, it is good to have one week in which we focus on statistical inference. The major difference between machine learning and statistics is their purpose. Machine learning models are designed to make accurate predictions. Statistical models are designed for inference about the relationships between variables. “Statistics draws population inferences from a sample, and machine learning finds generalizable predictive patterns” (Bzdok et al. 2018). Of course, this is a little bit of a blunt way to summarise the differences. Think of a linear regression model: using a train data set it can be used to make predictions about a test data set but when implemented as a statistical model it is used to find the line that minimises the mean squared error accross all data and can be used to characterise the relationshiop between the independent variables and the dependent variable.
